DataElement.preferredName: Treating Institution Stereotactic Radiosurgery Administered Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the name of the organization where stereotactic radiosurgery, a radiation therapy technique involving a rigid head frame that is attached to the skull; high-dose radiation is administered through openings in the head frame to the tumor while decreasing the amount of radiation given to normal brain tissue, was administered.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the organization where stereotactic radiosurgery, a radiation therapy technique involving a rigid head frame that is attached to the skull; high-dose radiation is administered through openings in the head frame to the tumor while decreasing the amount of radiation given to normal brain tissue, was administered.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Treating; providing treatment for.:The buildings and organizations where healthcare services are provided.

Concepts.definition: The buildings and organizations where healthcare services are provided.

Property.preferredDefinition: (STAIR-ee-o-TAK-tik...) A radiation therapy technique involving a rigid head frame that is attached to the skull; high-dose radiation is administered through openings in the head frame to the tumor while decreasing the amount of radiation given to normal brain tissue. This procedure does not involve surgery.:Given.

Concepts.definition: A non-surgical procedure that was developed to deliver one or several maximum dose targeted radiation treatments for cancers in the brain or spine.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The buildings and organizations where healthcare services are provided.:Personal names, given or surname, as cultural characteristics, as ethnological or religious patterns, as indications of the geographic distribution of families and inbreeding, etc. Analysis of isonymy, the quality of having the same or similar names, is useful in the study of population genetics. NAMES is used also for the history of names or name changes of corporate bodies, such as medical societies, universities, hospitals, government agencies, etc.

A word or group of words indicating the identity of a person usually consisting of a first (personal) name and a last (family) name with an optional middle name. In some cultural traditions the family name comes first.
